models.name: AuditStamp
models.doc: Data captured on a resource/association/sub-resource level giving insight into when that resource/association/sub-resource moved into a particular lifecycle stage, and who acted to move it into that specific lifecycle stage.

fields.name: time

type.name: Time
type.doc: Number of milliseconds since midnight, January 1, 1970 UTC. It must be a positive number

fields.doc: When did the resource/association/sub-resource move into the specific lifecycle stage represented by this AuditEvent.

fields.name: actor
fields.doc: The entity (e.g. a member URN) which will be credited for moving the resource/association/sub-resource into the specific lifecycle stage. It is also the one used to authorize the change.

fields.name: impersonator
fields.doc: The entity (e.g. a service URN) which performs the change on behalf of the Actor and must be authorized to act as the Actor.

models.name: ChangeAuditStamps
models.doc: Data captured on a resource/association/sub-resource level giving insight into when that resource/association/sub-resource moved into various lifecycle stages, and who acted to move it into those lifecycle stages. The recommended best practice is to include this record in your record schema, and annotate its fields as @readOnly in your resource. See https://github.com/linkedin/rest.li/wiki/Validation-in-Rest.li#restli-validation-annotations

fields.name: created
fields.doc: An AuditStamp corresponding to the creation of this resource/association/sub-resource

fields.name: lastModified
fields.doc: An AuditStamp corresponding to the last modification of this resource/association/sub-resource. If no modification has happened since creation, lastModified should be the same as created

fields.name: deleted
fields.doc: An AuditStamp corresponding to the deletion of this resource/association/sub-resource. Logically, deleted MUST have a later timestamp than creation. It may or may not have the same time as lastModified depending upon the resource/association/sub-resource semantics.

fields.name: owner
fields.doc:
Owner URN, e.g. urn:li:corpuser:ldap, urn:li:corpGroup:group_name, and urn:li:multiProduct:mp_name
(Caveat: only corpuser is currently supported in the frontend.)

fields.name: type

symbolDocs.CONSUMER: A person, group, or service that consumes the data
symbolDocs.DATAOWNER: A person or group that is owning the data
symbolDocs.DELEGATE: A person or a group that overseas the operation, e.g. a DBA or SRE.
symbolDocs.DEVELOPER: A person or group that is in charge of developing the code
symbolDocs.PRODUCER: A person, group, or service that produces/generates the data
symbolDocs.STAKEHOLDER: A person or a group that has direct business interest

fields.doc: The type of the ownership

fields.name: source
type

symbolDocs.SERVICE: Other ownership-like service, e.g. Nuage, ACL service etc

fields.doc: The type of the source

fields.name: url
fields.doc: A reference URL for the source
Source information for the ownership

fields.name: owners
fields.doc: List of owners of the entity.

fields.name: lastModified
fields.doc: Audit stamp containing who last modified the record and when.
tag name
fields.name: name

models.name: TagAspect
models.doc: A union of all supported metadata aspects for a tag

fields.name: name
fields.doc: Name of the tag

fields.name: description
fields.doc: Documentation of the tag

models.name: BackfillResult
models.doc: The model for the result of a backfill

fields.name: entities
urn
fields.doc: Urn of the backfilled entity

fields.name: aspects
fields.doc: List of the aspects backfilled for the entity
List of backfilled entities

models.name: TagSnapshot
models.doc: A metadata snapshot for a specific dataset entity.

fields.name: urn
fields.doc: URN for the entity the metadata snapshot is associated with.

fields.name: aspects
fields.doc: The list of metadata aspects associated with the dataset. Depending on the use case, this can either be all, or a selection, of supported aspects.

models.name: EmptyRecord
models.doc: An literally empty record.  Intended as a marker to indicate the absence of content where a record type is required.  If used the underlying DataMap *must* be empty, EmptyRecordValidator is provided to help enforce this.  For example,  CreateRequest extends Request<EmptyRecord> to indicate it has no response body.   Also, a ComplexKeyResource implementation that has no ParamKey should have a signature like XyzResource implements ComplexKeyResource<XyzKey, EmptyRecord, Xyz>.

models.name: Tag
models.doc: Dataset spec for a data store. A collection of data conforming to a single schema that can evolve over time. This is equivalent to a Table in most data platforms. Espresso dataset: Identity.Profile; oracle dataset: member2.member_profile; hdfs dataset: /data/databases/JOBS/JOB_APPLICATIONS; kafka: PageViewEvent

fields.name: name
fields.doc: tag name

fields.name: urn
fields.doc: Tag urn

fields.name: description
fields.doc: description of the tag

fields.name: ownership
fields.doc: Ownership metadata of the dataset
